title: Education @ HMC
text:
The General Engineering Program at Harvey Mudd College stands out for its interdisciplinary approach, blending mechanical, electrical, and systems engineering with a strong foundation in liberal arts and sciences. Students gain technical expertise and hands-on experience through project-based learning, cutting-edge labs, and the renowned Clinic Program, where they solve real-world problems with industry partners. Emphasizing ethical innovation and societal impact, the program prepares well-rounded engineers equipped to tackle complex challenges across industries. With its rigorous curriculum, collaborative learning environment, and strong alumni network, HMC’s program produces technically proficient, socially conscious leaders ready to excel in a dynamic world.



In some of my completed courses, I worked on some challenging, interesting, and fun final projects. Information about each final project can be found below, and the final report for each project is linked.
Inverted Pendulum Control System: A partner and I developed a full-state feedback control system that stabilized an inverted pendulum on a cart as it moved 1 meter in under 10 seconds.

More information can be found here.

Driveshaft Analysis of a Formula SAE RaceCar: I conducted a material analysis of a driveshaft used on Formula SAE vehicles.

More information can be found here.

Underwater Submarine: A team of 3 students and I developed a underwater submarine whose objective was to determine the change in salinity of water at Dana Point due to climate change.

More information about the presentation can be found here.


More information about the final report can be found here.




Check out the course descriptions here: Engineering Curriculum @ HMC

title: Machine Shop
text:
Machine Shop Proctor
As a machine shop proctor at the Harvey Mudd Machine Shop, I had the opportunity to teach over 100 students every semester how to safely operate machinery in the metal and wood shop. As a shop proctor, I have helped students in their journeys creating ocarinas and hammers in the shop in safe manner while fostering a welcoming environment.

title: Visa
text:
Role: Technical Product Manager Intern.
Technical Skills: Agile, Scrum, Kubernetes, Python, Estimation, Large Budget Management, Large Scale Infrastructure Management.
Soft Skills: Stakeholder Management, Listening, Leadership, Communication, Technical Communication, Time Management, Stress Management, Conflict Resolution.
To make the most of my internship at Visa, I knew that I had to be proactive. I actively sought out resources in the form of my weekly meetings with my manager, daily meetings with my buddy and lots of time spent on the intranet to try and get up to speed as quickly as possible. Once I was onboarded, I met with various different teams with my buddy and learnt a lot about the ins and out of large scale infrastructure management. Soon, I was trusted to manage 133 servers and a budget of $700,000. In addition to this I was asked to pitch the product in front of a large scale department meeting ## Team Dinner

title: Who is she?
text: My identity extends beyond the fact that I am an aspiring engineer. I am someone who is South Asian and I am really proud of this part of my identity. I was heavily involved with the Claremont Collleges South Asian Student Association. In my role as a board member, my team and I worked on fostering a more inclusive environment given that South Asia is a very multi-cultural subsection of Asia. We were able to host 10+ cultural events each academic year. We were able to handle large budgets skillfully while also tackling challenges like COVID.

title: Amazon Prime Air
text:
Tag Detection
import apriltag
import argparse
import cv2

# construct the argument parser and parse the arguments
ap = argparse.ArgumentParser()
ap.add_argument("-i", "--image", required=True,
    help="path to input image containing AprilTag")
args = vars(ap.parse_args())

# load the input image and convert it to grayscale
print("[INFO] loading image...")
image = cv2.imread(args["image"])
gray = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

# define the AprilTags detector options and then detect the AprilTags
# in the input image
print("[INFO] detecting AprilTags...")
options = apriltag.DetectorOptions(families="tag16h5")
detector = apriltag.Detector(options)
results = detector.detect(gray)
print("[INFO] {} total AprilTags detected".format(len(results)))


# loop over the AprilTag detection results
for r in results:
    # extract the bounding box (x, y)-coordinates for the AprilTag
    # and convert each of the (x, y)-coordinate pairs to integers
    (ptA, ptB, ptC, ptD) = r.corners
    ptB = (int(ptB[0]), int(ptB[1]))
    ptC = (int(ptC[0]), int(ptC[1]))
    ptD = (int(ptD[0]), int(ptD[1]))
    ptA = (int(ptA[0]), int(ptA[1]))
    # draw the bounding box of the AprilTag detection
    cv2.line(image, ptA, ptB, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptB, ptC, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptC, ptD, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptD, ptA, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    # draw the center (x, y)-coordinates of the AprilTag
    (cX, cY) = (int(r.center[0]), int(r.center[1]))
    cv2.circle(image, (cX, cY), 5, (0, 0, 255), -1)
    # draw the tag family on the image
    tagFamily = r.tag_family.decode("utf-8")
    cv2.putText(image, tagFamily, (ptA[0], ptA[1] - 15),
        cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, 0.5, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    print("[INFO] tag family: {}".format(tagFamily))
# show the output image after AprilTag detection
cv2.imshow("Image", image)
cv2.waitKey(0)

title: Amazon Prime Air
text:
Tag Detection Code
import apriltag
import argparse
import cv2

# construct the argument parser and parse the arguments
ap = argparse.ArgumentParser()
ap.add_argument("-i", "--image", required=True,
    help="path to input image containing AprilTag")
args = vars(ap.parse_args())

# load the input image and convert it to grayscale
print("[INFO] loading image...")
image = cv2.imread(args["image"])
gray = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

# define the AprilTags detector options and then detect the AprilTags
# in the input image
print("[INFO] detecting AprilTags...")
options = apriltag.DetectorOptions(families="tag16h5")
detector = apriltag.Detector(options)
results = detector.detect(gray)
print("[INFO] {} total AprilTags detected".format(len(results)))


# loop over the AprilTag detection results
for r in results:
    # extract the bounding box (x, y)-coordinates for the AprilTag
    # and convert each of the (x, y)-coordinate pairs to integers
    (ptA, ptB, ptC, ptD) = r.corners
    ptB = (int(ptB[0]), int(ptB[1]))
    ptC = (int(ptC[0]), int(ptC[1]))
    ptD = (int(ptD[0]), int(ptD[1]))
    ptA = (int(ptA[0]), int(ptA[1]))
    # draw the bounding box of the AprilTag detection
    cv2.line(image, ptA, ptB, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptB, ptC, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptC, ptD, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    cv2.line(image, ptD, ptA, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    # draw the center (x, y)-coordinates of the AprilTag
    (cX, cY) = (int(r.center[0]), int(r.center[1]))
    cv2.circle(image, (cX, cY), 5, (0, 0, 255), -1)
    # draw the tag family on the image
    tagFamily = r.tag_family.decode("utf-8")
    cv2.putText(image, tagFamily, (ptA[0], ptA[1] - 15),
        cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, 0.5, (0, 255, 0), 2)
    print("[INFO] tag family: {}".format(tagFamily))
# show the output image after AprilTag detection
cv2.imshow("Image", image)
cv2.waitKey(0)
